messages.content:
Document:
Opening Deposit
Monthly Maintenance
Fee
$25 or more
$4.95 each month. You can avoid the Monthly Maintenance Fee when you meet ONE of the following requirements during each statement cycle:
· Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in your account, OR
· An account owner, or child on a Family Banking account, is under the age of 25 (fiduciary accounts don't qualify), OR
· An owner of the account is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. Learn more at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
The document outlines the fees associated with a particular bank account. There is an opening deposit required, and a monthly maintenance fee of $4.95. However, there are ways to avoid this monthly fee. These include:

1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
1. The name of the account is not specified in the passage.
2. The initial deposit required to open the account is $25 or more.
3. The monthly maintenance fee for this account is $4.95.
4. The monthly maintenance fee can be avoided.
5. To avoid the monthly maintenance fee, one of the following conditions must be met:
a. Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
b. An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account must be under the age of 2



What are three ways to avoid the monthly maintenance fee for this bank account?

Three ways to avoid the monthly maintenance fee for this bank account are:
1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.

Document:
The document provides information on how to maximize the use of a bank account with Bank of America. To learn about the features and benefits of the account, customers can visit bankofamerica.com/quickstart. For any questions, they can schedule an appointment at bankofamerica.com/appointments or call 800.432.1000. It is recommended to review the Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures for the account's terms.

The document also specifies the following key points:

1. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking account owners and children cannot use some payment options.
2. Mobile Banking requires downloading the Mobile Banking app and is available only for select mobile devices, with message and data rates potentially applying.
3. Fees are applicable for wires and certain transfers, as detailed in the Online Banking Service Agreement at bankofamerica.com/serviceagreement.
4. Direct deposit and wire transfers are not available for SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts.
5. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts cannot receive incoming wire transfers.


Document:
Opening Deposit
Monthly Maintenance
Fee
$25 or more
$4.95 each month. You can avoid the Monthly Maintenance Fee when you meet ONE of the following requirements during each statement cycle:
· Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in your account, OR
· An account owner, or child on a Family Banking account, is under the age of 25 (fiduciary accounts don't qualify), OR
· An owner of the account is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. Learn more at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.



What is the Preferred Rewards program and how can it help avoid the monthly maintenance fee for this bank account?

The Preferred Rewards program is a separate enrollment program available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards. Enrolling in this program can help avoid the monthly maintenance fee for this bank account.

Document:
The document highlights the policy of no bank overdraft fees for a specific account. If an account lacks sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrawing. Although this prevents bank overdraft fees, merchants or third parties might charge fees for returned unpaid transactions. For instance, a late fee may be incurred if a payment is not received on time.

The account holder can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items. No charges apply for this service from the bank, but mobile carrier fees for messages and data may apply. Delivery of alerts can be impacted by the mobile carrier's coverage.

Despite the account's prevention of overdrawing in most cases, there are still potential scenarios where the account could show a negative balance without incurring an overdraft fee. These situations include:

• Circumstances not specified in the document.

messages.content:
Document:
1. The SafeBalance ® for Family Banking account has payment options that are unavailable for the account owner and child.
2. Bank of America's website, bankofamerica.com, has a feature called QuickStart that provides information about account features and benefits.
3. Bank of America's website, bankofamerica.com, allows users to schedule appointments to visit a financial center.
4. Bank of America can be contacted by phone at 800.432.1000.
5. The Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures contains terms for the account.
6. Mobile Banking is a service offered by Bank of America that requires downloading the Mobile Banking app.
7. Mobile Banking is only available for select mobile devices.
8. Message and data rates may apply for Mobile Banking.
9. Fees are applicable for certain transfers and wires.
10. The Online Banking Service Agreement at bankofamerica.com/serviceagreement contains details about fees for wires and certain transfers.
11. Direct deposit is not available for SafeBalance ® for Family Banking accounts.
12. Incoming wire transfers are not available for SafeBalance ® for Family Banking accounts.


Document:
The document outlines the fees associated with a particular bank account. There is an opening deposit required, and a monthly maintenance fee of $4.95. However, there are ways to avoid this monthly fee. These include:

1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
To maximize the benefits of your new bank account with Bank of America, visit their website at bankofamerica.com/quickstart to explore its features and advantages. For any inquiries, you can schedule an appointment at bankofamerica.com/appointments or call them at 800.432.1000. It is essential to review the Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures for the terms of your account. Please note the following key points:

1. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking account owners and children cannot use some payment options.
2. Mobile Banking requires downloading the app and is compatible with select mobile devices; message and data rates may apply.
3. Fees are applicable for wires and specific transfers, as outlined in the Online Banking Service Agreement at bankofamerica.com/serviceagreement.
4. Direct deposit and wire transfers are not available for SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts.
5. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts cannot receive incoming wire transfers.


Document:
1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.
2. Transactions are declined and returned unpaid when there is not enough money in the account to cover the transaction.
3. If a transaction is declined due to insufficient funds, the merchant or third party could charge a fee.
4. An example of a fee that a merchant or third party could charge is a late fee.
5. An account owner can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items.
6. The service of providing alerts is free, but mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply.
7. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by the mobile carrier's coverage.
8. There may still be instances where the account has a negative balance, but the bank will not charge an overdraft fee.
9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.



What is the role of the Preferred Rewards program in relation to the minimum daily balance requirement for this bank account?
The Preferred Rewards program is a separate enrollment program that can help account holders avoid the monthly maintenance fee for this bank account, regardless of the account balance.

messages.content:
Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account affects your balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within them are listed below, in the order they are generally posted:

1. Deposits: These are added from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals. They are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the date and time are not received, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These, such as scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments using your account number, are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

Please note that while transactions are processing, they may lower your available balance. Also, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
1. The SafeBalance ® for Family Banking account has payment options that are unavailable for the account owner and child.
2. Bank of America's website, bankofamerica.com, has a feature called QuickStart that provides information about account features and benefits.
3. Bank of America's website, bankofamerica.com, allows users to schedule appointments to visit a financial center.
4. Bank of America can be contacted by phone at 800.432.1000.
5. The Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures contains terms for the account.
6. Mobile Banking is a service offered by Bank of America that requires downloading the Mobile Banking app.
7. Mobile Banking is only available for select mobile devices.
8. Message and data rates may apply for Mobile Banking.
9. Fees are applicable for certain transfers and wires.
10. The Online Banking Service Agreement at bankofamerica.com/serviceagreement contains details about fees for wires and certain transfers.
11. Direct deposit is not available for SafeBalance ® for Family Banking accounts.
12. Incoming wire transfers are not available for SafeBalance ® for Family Banking accounts.


Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.

messages.content:
Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.


Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
The document highlights the policy of no bank overdraft fees for a specific account. If an account lacks sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrawing. Although this prevents bank overdraft fees, merchants or third parties might charge fees for returned unpaid transactions. For instance, a late fee may be incurred if a payment is not received on time.

The account holder can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items. No charges apply for this service from the bank, but mobile carrier fees for messages and data may apply. Delivery of alerts can be impacted by the mobile carrier's coverage.

Despite the account's prevention of overdrawing in most cases, there are still potential scenarios where the account could show a negative balance without incurring an overdraft fee. These situations include:

• Circumstances not specified in the document.



How does the Preferred Rewards program contribute to understanding the fee structure for this bank account?

The Preferred Rewards program is a separate enrollment program that can help account holders avoid the monthly maintenance fee for this bank account, providing an additional layer of flexibility in the fee structure.

messages.content:
Document:
To maximize the benefits of your new bank account with Bank of America, visit their website at bankofamerica.com/quickstart to explore its features and advantages. For any inquiries, you can schedule an appointment at bankofamerica.com/appointments or call them at 800.432.1000. It is essential to review the Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures for the terms of your account. Please note the following key points:

1. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking account owners and children cannot use some payment options.
2. Mobile Banking requires downloading the app and is compatible with select mobile devices; message and data rates may apply.
3. Fees are applicable for wires and specific transfers, as outlined in the Online Banking Service Agreement at bankofamerica.com/serviceagreement.
4. Direct deposit and wire transfers are not available for SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts.
5. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts cannot receive incoming wire transfers.

Document:
Opening Deposit
Monthly Maintenance
Fee
$25 or more
$4.95 each month. You can avoid the Monthly Maintenance Fee when you meet ONE of the following requirements during each statement cycle:
· Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in your account, OR
· An account owner, or child on a Family Banking account, is under the age of 25 (fiduciary accounts don't qualify), OR
· An owner of the account is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. Learn more at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.



What is the minimum initial deposit required to open the account?
The minimum initial deposit required to open the account is $25 or more.

Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account affects your balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within them are listed below, in the order they are generally posted:

1. Deposits: These are added from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals. They are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the date and time are not received, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These, such as scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments using your account number, are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

Please note that while transactions are processing, they may lower your available balance. Also, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:

Document:
1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.

4. An example of a fee that a merchant or third party could charge is a late fee.
5. An account owner can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items.
6. The service of providing alerts is free, but mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply.
7. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by the mobile carrier's coverage.
8. There may still be instances where the account has a negative balance, but the bank will not charge an overdraft fee.
9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.

The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. · Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.



What are the requirements for maintaining a minimum daily balance in this account?
To maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in this account, the account owner must ensure that the balance does not fall below this amount at any point during the statement cycle.

Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. 3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

Monthly Maintenance

$25 or more
$4.95 each month. You can avoid the Monthly Maintenance Fee when you meet ONE of the following requirements during each statement cycle:
· Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in your account, OR
· An account owner, or child on a Family Banking account, is under the age of 25 (fiduciary accounts don't qualify), OR
· An owner of the account is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. Learn more at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.



What types of transactions incur fees in Bank of America accounts?
Fees are applicable for wires and certain transfers, as detailed in the Online Banking Service Agreement at bankofamerica.com/serviceagreement.

messages.content:
Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:


Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.


Document:
1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.
2. Transactions are declined and returned unpaid when there is not enough money in the account to cover the transaction.
3. If a transaction is declined due to insufficient funds, the merchant or third party could charge a fee.
4. An example of a fee that a merchant or third party could charge is a late fee.
5. An account owner can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items.
6. The service of providing alerts is free, but mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply.
7. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by the mobile carrier's coverage.
8. There may still be instances where the account has a negative balance, but the bank will not charge an overdraft fee.
9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.

Document:
The document highlights the policy of no bank overdraft fees for a specific account. If an account lacks sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrawing. Although this prevents bank overdraft fees, merchants or third parties might charge fees for returned unpaid transactions. For instance, a late fee may be incurred if a payment is not received on time.

The account holder can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items. No charges apply for this service from the bank, but mobile carrier fees for messages and data may apply. Delivery of alerts can be impacted by the mobile carrier's coverage.

Despite the account's prevention of overdrawing in most cases, there are still potential scenarios where the account could show a negative balance without incurring an overdraft fee. These situations include:

• Circumstances not specified in the document.


Document:
1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.
2. Transactions are declined and returned unpaid when there is not enough money in the account to cover the transaction.
3. If a transaction is declined due to insufficient funds, the merchant or third party could charge a fee.
4. An example of a fee that a merchant or third party could charge is a late fee.
5. An account owner can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items.
6. The service of providing alerts is free, but mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply.
7. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by the mobile carrier's coverage.
8. There may still be instances where the account has a negative balance, but the bank will not charge an overdraft fee.
9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.


Document:
Opening Deposit
Monthly Maintenance
Fee
$25 or more
$4.95 each month. You can avoid the Monthly Maintenance Fee when you meet ONE of the following requirements during each statement cycle:
· Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in your account, OR
· An account owner, or child on a Family Banking account, is under the age of 25 (fiduciary accounts don't qualify), OR
· An owner of the account is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. Learn more at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.

1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.

b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.

d. Situations where the bank has made an error.

Document:
The key points of the document are as follows:

1. The document pertains to the terms of a bank account, which has an opening deposit and a monthly maintenance fee.
2. The monthly maintenance fee is $4.95.
3. The monthly maintenance fee can be avoided if one of the following conditions is met during each statement cycle:
	- A minimum daily balance of $500 or more is maintained in the account.
	- An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
	- An account owner is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. More information about this program can be found at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account affects your balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within them are listed below, in the order they are generally posted:

1. Deposits: These are added from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals. They are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the date and time are not received, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These, such as scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments using your account number, are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

Please note that while transactions are processing, they may lower your available balance. Also, paper checks are not compatible with this account.



Which type of account cannot receive incoming wire transfers?
SafeBalance ® for Family Banking accounts cannot receive incoming wire transfers.

Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.



Where can one find the terms and conditions for their Bank of America account?
It is essential to review the Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures for the terms of your account.

This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.

Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.


Document:
The document outlines the fees associated with a particular bank account. There is an opening deposit required, and a monthly maintenance fee of $4.95. However, there are ways to avoid this monthly fee. These include:

1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.

5. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts cannot receive incoming wire transfers.

Document:
1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.
2. Transactions are declined and returned unpaid when there is not enough money in the account to cover the transaction.
3. If a transaction is declined due to insufficient funds, the merchant or third party could charge a fee.
4. An example of a fee that a merchant or third party could charge is a late fee.
5. An account owner can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items.
6. The service of providing alerts is free, but mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply.
7. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by the mobile carrier's coverage.
8. There may still be instances where the account has a negative balance, but the bank will not charge an overdraft fee.
9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.

messages.content:
Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
The document outlines the fees associated with a particular bank account. There is an opening deposit required, and a monthly maintenance fee of $4.95. However, there are ways to avoid this monthly fee. These include:

1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:

	- A minimum daily balance of $500 or more is maintained in the account.
	- An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
	- An account owner is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. More information about this program can be found at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.

SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking accounts cannot receive incoming wire transfers.

messages.content:
Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.



What type of account is the SafeBalance ® for Family Banking account?
The SafeBalance ® for Family Banking account is a type of account that does not allow owners and children to use some payment options.

We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:


Document:
1. The name of the account is not specified in the passage.
2. The initial deposit required to open the account is $25 or more.
3. The monthly maintenance fee for this account is $4.95.
4. The monthly maintenance fee can be avoided.
5. To avoid the monthly maintenance fee, one of the following conditions must be met:
a. Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
b. An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account must be under the age of 2


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.

messages.content:
Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

3. The monthly maintenance fee can be avoided if one of the following conditions is met during each statement cycle:
	- A minimum daily balance of $500 or more is maintained in the account.
	- An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
	- An account owner is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. More information about this program can be found at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account affects your balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within them are listed below, in the order they are generally posted:

1. Deposits: These are added from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals. They are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the date and time are not received, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These, such as scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments using your account number, are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

Please note that while transactions are processing, they may lower your available balance. Also, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:



What are the requirements for using Mobile Banking with Bank of America?
To use Mobile Banking with Bank of America, you need to download the app and ensure that your mobile device is compatible with the service. Additionally, message and data rates may apply.

Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

Document:
1. This account does not charge overdraft fees.
2. Transactions are declined and returned unpaid when there is not enough money in the account to cover the transaction.
3. If a transaction is declined due to insufficient funds, the merchant or third party could charge a fee.
4. An example of a fee that a merchant or third party could charge is a late fee.
5. An account owner can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items.
6. The service of providing alerts is free, but mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply.
7. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by the mobile carrier's coverage.
8. There may still be instances where the account has a negative balance, but the bank will not charge an overdraft fee.
9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.


Document:
1. The name of the account is not specified in the passage.
2. The initial deposit required to open the account is $25 or more.
3. The monthly maintenance fee for this account is $4.95.
4. The monthly maintenance fee can be avoided.
5. To avoid the monthly maintenance fee, one of the following conditions must be met:
a. Maintain a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
b. An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account must be under the age of 2


Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:

messages.content:
Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account affects your balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within them are listed below, in the order they are generally posted:

1. Deposits: These are added from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals. They are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the date and time are not received, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These, such as scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments using your account number, are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

Please note that while transactions are processing, they may lower your available balance. Also, paper checks are not compatible with this account.

1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:

We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.

· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:

	- A minimum daily balance of $500 or more is maintained in the account.
	- An account owner or a child on a Family Banking account is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
	- An account owner is a member of the Preferred Rewards program. More information about this program can be found at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
The document highlights the policy of no bank overdraft fees for a specific account. If an account lacks sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrawing. Although this prevents bank overdraft fees, merchants or third parties might charge fees for returned unpaid transactions. For instance, a late fee may be incurred if a payment is not received on time.

The account holder can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items. No charges apply for this service from the bank, but mobile carrier fees for messages and data may apply. Delivery of alerts can be impacted by the mobile carrier's coverage.

Despite the account's prevention of overdrawing in most cases, there are still potential scenarios where the account could show a negative balance without incurring an overdraft fee. These situations include:

• Circumstances not specified in the document.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.

d. Situations where the bank has made an error.



What kind of account is a SafeBalance ® for Family Banking account?

A SafeBalance ® for Family Banking account is a type of account that has certain restrictions on payment options. For instance, direct deposit and wire transfers aren't available for this account, and it can't receive incoming wire transfers.

• Most fees:

Document:
The document highlights the policy of no bank overdraft fees for a specific account. If an account lacks sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrawing. Although this prevents bank overdraft fees, merchants or third parties might charge fees for returned unpaid transactions. For instance, a late fee may be incurred if a payment is not received on time.

The account holder can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items. No charges apply for this service from the bank, but mobile carrier fees for messages and data may apply. Delivery of alerts can be impacted by the mobile carrier's coverage.

Despite the account's prevention of overdrawing in most cases, there are still potential scenarios where the account could show a negative balance without incurring an overdraft fee. These situations include:

• Circumstances not specified in the document.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.


Document:
No bank overdraft fees
We don't charge overdraft fees on this account. To help you avoid overdrawing your account, transactions will be declined and returned unpaid when you don't have enough money in your account.
· If this happens, you won't be charged a bank overdraft fee, but the merchant or third party could charge you a fee. For example, you may be charged a late fee if the payment isn't received on time.
· An owner can set up email or mobile alerts to notify you when you have a low balance in your account or when items aren't paid. (We don't charge for this service but your mobile carrier's message and data fees may apply. Delivery of alerts may be affected or delayed by your mobile carrier's coverage.)
While this account prevents you from overdrawing in most cases, there may still be times when your account could have a negative balance, but we won't charge an overdraft fee. This could happen in the following ways:



What services does the bank provide for low balance or unpaid item alerts, and what are the associated costs?
The bank provides email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items free of charge. However, mobile carrier fees for messages and data may apply.

Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

9. Examples of situations where the account could have a negative balance but no overdraft fee is charged include:
a. Scheduled recurring payments or withdrawals that overdraw the account.
b. Overdrafts caused by transactions that are processed more than once.
c. Transactions that are posted to the account with incorrect amounts.
d. Situations where the bank has made an error.


Document:
The document outlines the fees associated with a particular bank account. There is an opening deposit required, and a monthly maintenance fee of $4.95. However, there are ways to avoid this monthly fee. These include:

1. Maintaining a minimum daily balance of $500 or more in the account.
2. Having an account owner or a child on a Family Banking account who is under the age of 25, except for fiduciary accounts.
3. Being a member of the Preferred Rewards program, which requires separate enrollment available at bankofamerica.com/preferred-rewards.


Document:
The method of posting transactions to your account by the bank affects your account balance. At the end of each business day, transactions received that day are categorized and then posted. The common categories and typical transactions within each are listed in the order they generally post to your account:

1. Deposits: These are added to your account from the highest to the lowest dollar amount.
2. Many debit transactions: These are subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If the bank's system does not receive the date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers, and ATM withdrawals.
3. Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: These are subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. This category includes scheduled transfers, online bill payments, and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
4. Most fees: These are also subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.

It is important to note that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance. Additionally, paper checks are not compatible with this account.



How can account owners stay informed about their account balance to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees?

Account owners can stay informed about their account balance by monitoring their account balance regularly and setting up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, which is a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. This helps prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

Document:
How we post transactions
The way we post transactions impacts your account balance. At the end of each business day, we'll group transactions received that day into categories before posting them. Below are the most common categories, and common transaction types in each, in the order that they generally post to your account. Keep in mind that transactions that are still processing may lower your available balance.
· Deposits: Added from highest to lowest dollar amount.
· Many debit transactions: Subtracted based on the date and time you made them. If our system doesn't receive date and time of the transaction, they are posted and subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include one-time and recurring debit card transactions, one-time transfers and ATM withdrawals.
· Most other electronic payments and preauthorized transfers: Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amount. These include scheduled transfers, online bill payments and preauthorized payments that use your account number.
• Most fees:
Subtracted from highest to lowest dollar amounts.
Reminder: Paper checks will not work with this account.


Document:
This account does not impose overdraft fees. If you lack sufficient funds, transactions will be declined to prevent overdrafts, avoiding bank overdraft fees. However, merchants or third parties might charge you fees, such as late fees if payments are not received on time. Account owners can set up email or mobile alerts for low balances or unpaid items, a free service, although mobile carrier fees may apply. Despite these safeguards, there may be instances where your account has a negative balance without incurring overdraft fees. This can occur through various means, such as:

1. If you have previously authorized overdraft transactions, like checks or recurring debit card payments, they may still be processed, resulting in a negative balance.
2. If you have opted in for overdraft protection, linked to another account or a line of credit, and there are insufficient funds in the primary account, overdraft fees from the secondary account may apply.
3. If you have a negative balance due to bank errors or adjustments, no overdraft fee will be charged.

It is essential to monitor your account balance and set up alerts to prevent unexpected negative balances and potential merchant fees.

It is recommended to review the Personal Schedule of Fees and Deposit Agreement and Disclosures for the account's terms.

The document also specifies the following key points:

1. SafeBalance ®  for Family Banking account owners and children cannot use some payment options.
